In which direction in the sky was the location of the big bang? This video suggests you can see it in every direction. But if it really were a singular point, it could not possibly be in all directions.  It would need to be in some specific direction. So, which direction is it?

We can’t see the big bang, because we were there at that time, and the light that left then has gone past us already. Nor can we see the universe 1 year after the big bang, because even the furthest part of the universe from us at that time was so close that its light has gone past us by now, too.  So the question is, how far back in time is it possible for us to see?

All this is a bullAll this is a bullshit.
How to sound deep:

If everything (matter and light) came from a single point, (the Big Bang) in order to see it now we would need to be traveling faster than the speed of the light that came from that moment, but nothing travel faster than the speed of light... so how would be possible to see the origins of the universe then? ....Confused

This is beautifully written, however, at 0:59 it is said that "if we peer out far enough, in between the galaxies, we can see parts of the universe that are so far away, it has taken the light from that distance, very nearly the entire age of the cosmos to reach us. ... we see parts of the universe that are so far from the past, they're still in the final stages of the big bang."
This is clearly a reflection of the observed red shift in the cosmic background, but it should be noted that the big bang is still just a theory, and the red shift we observe in the cosmic background may turn out to be something not at all related to the big bang, like, what if the red was not even coming from the farthest distances in space, but from ripples in the voids of space, and the red shift is simply the effect of the light escaping a gravity well.
My point is, nobody knows if the big bang theory is true or not. I believe it is foolish to portray a universe where the reality of that theory is absolute.

“We are looking back into the past” - I hate this phrase. This is a bad phrase, caused by the bad definition of “present” and “past”. It was defined long ago, when we didn’t know about general relativity, or the speed of light, and we believed, information travels instantly.
When we say “this star might be exploded already, but we don’t know because the light didn’t get here yet” we are wrong. There is no way knowing it, so the possible explosion of the star is NOT the unknown past, but it is in fact the future in every rational way.

I propose an improved definition of “present”. Present is the wavefront of information getting here at this moment, traveling with the speed of light (speed of causality). Present is what I see. Everything before it, is the past and everything getting here later is the future. This would be the fundamental definition, which matches with our own intuition as well.

If I see a star exploding, it is happening now. The Big bang is happening now, it is a continuous process which is currently about at the edge of the observable universe.

Let’s realize, that the speed of light (speed of causality) is such a fundamental concept in the universe, that it worth defining time itself by it. Especially because the concept of time itself is derived from C, which is more fundamental than time itself.

Something that has always fascinated and bothered me about our understanding of the universe is that it's impossible to get an effective instantaneous snapshot of it. We see things that are billions of light years away, but that light is from billions of years ago; where are they now?

Our knowledge of the universe is inherently conical (as in a space-time diagram) and can only flatten out over time as we observe and keep records.

As someone from US, I think using imperial units is rather outdated and non-useful, and I wish we switched to metric for day-to-day tasks.  However, I also thoroughly enjoy watching non-US guys get a meltdown whenever a foot or a degree Fahrenheit shows up.  Therefore, I will continue to support the imperial system :)

I think the dramatic tone that makes space sound cool in this video is bad.  Things like “creation” and “fire” are misleading.  It’s best to talk about what we know about inflation rather than what we want to apply to it.  The observations are not “the universe was forged in the blahblahblah”.  The observation is the oldest stuff we can see was a dense hot sphere.  There is probably stuff past that but it’s too far away to see.  For now we can’t say too much about what happened before then but people are working on theories of quantum gravity to get a better idea.  Not as sexy right?  It’s still cool and shouldn’t be covered up to grab attention.

Time zero is in every direction. The sphere of time zero is expanding at one light-second per second. At any given point there is a unique sphere of time zero. That sphere contains all that could have affected that location in space -- the light 'cone.' From every point at every moment there is an emerging sphere of new reality; the future light 'cone' expanding in radius at one light-second/second.

My time passes at one second per second. So does yours. Yet, we may disagree as to how many seconds have passed as we go from being together to being apart and then back together again. Acceleration slows time as seen by non-accelerating observers. At the surface of a black hole time stops altogether as seen by outside observers; nothing actually enters the black hole, ever, from our perspective.

Time is passing strange.
